textline.text: MARIANA CRACIUN
Science in Human Culture Program
Department of Sociology
Northwestern University
CONTACT
Science in Human Culture
University Hall, Room 020
Phone (office): 847.491.3525
Northwestern University Email: mariana.craciun@northwestern.edu
1497 Sheridan Rd., Evanston, IL, 60208
ACADEMIC POSITIONS
NSF Postdoctoral Fellow, Northwestern University
Science in Human Culture Program and Department of Sociology
Postdoctoral Fellow, Northwestern University 2013 – 2015
Science in Human Culture Program and Department of Sociology
EDUCATION
Ph.D. Sociology, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor
Dissertation: “Embodied Expertise: The Science and Affect of Psychotherapy”
Committee: Jason Owen-Smith (chair); Renee Anspach; John Carson (History);
George Steinmetz; Genevieve Zubrzycki
M.A. Sociology, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor
Preliminary Examination: Culture and Knowledge
B.A. Sociology (Anthropology Minor), University of California, Los Angeles
Summa cum laude
Completed the Transfer Alliance Honors Program, Los Angeles Valley College
Academy of Economic Studies, Bucharest, Romania
RESEARCH AND TEACHING AREAS
Sociological Theory, Qualitative Methods, Sociology of Medicine, Social Studies of Science,
Expertise and Professions, Immigration
PUBLICATIONS
Craciun, Mariana. 2013. “Moral Bricolage and Immigrant Identification: The Case of
Romanian Americans.” Ethnic and Racial Studies. 36(5): 729-746.
Craciun, Mariana. “Charismatic Practices: Power and Emotion in Psychotherapy.” (Conditional
Accept at Theory and Society)
Craciun, Mariana. 2015. Review of Misbehaving Science: Controversy and the Development of
Behavior Genetics by Aaron Panofsky. New Genetics and Society.
WRITING IN PROGRESS
Book Manuscript:
Chasing Freud’s Dream: Psychotherapy between Science and Emotions
(Manuscript in preparation)
Articles:
Craciun, Mariana. “Towards a Model of Affective-Relational Expertise: A Comparison
of Two Psychotherapies.” (Revise and Resubmit at the American Journal of
Sociology)
Craciun, Mariana. “The Time of Psychotherapy: A Comparison of Psychoanalytic and
‘Evidence-Based’ Approaches.” (Revise and Resubmit at Qualitative Sociology)
Craciun, Mariana and Jason Owen-Smith. “Funding Human Embryonic Stem Cell
Research: Science and Scientists in Congress.” (Manuscript drafted)
Craciun, Mariana and Gil Eyal. “What do Therapists do? Towards a Sociology of
Treatments.” (Manuscript in preparation)
FELLOWSHIPS AND GRANTS
National Science Foundation, Science and Technology Studies Program. Postdoctoral
Fellowship and Grant for “The Science of Talk: Constructing Evidence-Based
Psychotherapy.” 2015 – 2017
Faculty Research Grant ($5,000), Northwestern University, 2014 – 2015
Rackham Predoctoral Fellowship, Horace H. Rackham School of Graduate Studies, University of

Mellon Dissertation Seminar in the Humanities, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, 2013
(declined)

Graduate Student Research Grant, Horace H. Rackham School of Graduate Studies, University

Sociology Dissertation Research Grant, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, 2010
Spring/Summer Research Grant, Horace H. Rackham School of Graduate Studies, University of
Michigan, Ann Arbor (Co-PI with Jason Owen-Smith), 2007
LS&A Regents Fellowship, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, 2005 – 2006
INVITED PRESENTATIONS
“The Affect and Science of Psychotherapy: A Comparison of Psychoanalytic and ‘Evidence-
Based’ Approaches.” Chicago Psychoanalytic Institute, May 2015.
“The Affect and Science of Psychotherapy: A Comparison of Psychoanalytic and ‘Evidence-
Based’ Approaches.” University of Illinois, Chicago, Health and Society Working

“The Affect and Science of Psychotherapy.” Northwestern University, Science in Human

“Emotions as Vehicles of Expertise: A Comparison of Psychodynamic and Cognitive-

November 2012
REFEREED CONFERENCE PRESENTATIONS
“The time of psychotherapy: A Comparison of Psychoanalytic and Evidence-Based
Approaches.” American Sociological Association, Chicago, IL, August 2015
Discussant comments, presented at a panel on “Debating the Biologization of Mental Illness,” at

“Charismatic Practices: Power and Affect in Psychotherapy.” American Sociological
Association, San Francisco, CA, August 2014
Discussant comments, presented at a panel on “Knowledge, Expertise and Systems Production,”
at the 16th Annual Chicago Ethnography Conference, Evanson, IL, March 2014
“Affect and Expertise in Psychotherapy: A Comparison of Psychoanalytic and ‘Evidence-
Based’ Practices.” Eastern Sociological Society, Mini-Conference on “Invisible Work,”
Baltimore, MD, March 2014
“A Case for Charisma as Skill: The Affective and Relational Underpinnings of
Psychotherapeutic Authority.” Social Science History Association, Chicago, IL,
November 2013
“Temporal Practices in Psychotherapy: A Comparison of ‘Evidence-Based’ and Psychoanalytic
Approaches.” Society for Social Studies of Science, San Diego, CA, October 2013
“The Science of Mental Illness: Inscription and Quantification in the Work of Psychotherapists.”
American Sociological Association, New York, NY, August 2013
“Emotions as Vehicles of Expertise: A Comparison of Psychodynamic and Cognitive-
Behavioral Psychotherapists.” American Sociological Association, Denver, CO, August
“Beyond Clock and Couch: The Role of Time and Place in Psychotherapeutic Expertise.” 14th
Annual Chicago Ethnography Conference, Chicago, IL, March 2012
“Immigrant Identity within a ‘Spectrum’ of Americanness: The Case of Romanian Immigrants.”
American Sociological Association, San Francisco, CA, August 2009
“Immigration as a Boundary-Drawing Cultural Process: The Case of Romanian Immigrants.”
American Sociological Association, Boston, MA, August 2008

Northwestern University
Instructor

Sociological Theory, 2008

Research Assistant for Mark Mizruchi: “The Changing Nature of the American Corporate Elite,
Research Assistant for Jason Owen-Smith on the “United States Knowledge Economy Project.”

PROFESSIONAL SERVICE
Member, the Hacker-Mullins Award Committee, Science, Knowledge and Technology Section

Panel co-organizer, “Revolution, Routine, and Remedy: New Work on Charisma, Culture and

Ad hoc reviewer, American Journal of Sociology, Social Science & Medicine, Qualitative
